Help.#cdata:
Enables you to comply with section 508 of the Rehabilitation Acts and meet usability 
requirements for disabled users. Specifying the ACCESSIBLE option, when used with the 
ODS HTML statement, generates descriptive text and data for your graphs. SAS/GRAPH 
writes accessibility information to the graph's output HTML file, and creates a left-
justified footnote that provides a link to the information.
Toggles off the ACCESSIBLE option.
Instructs the GDDM device driver to write out an ADMGDF file.
Instructs the GDDM device driver to write out a GDF file.

Syntax: ASPECT=scaling-factor

where scaling-factor is a nonnegative integer or real number that determines the 
ratio of width to height for graphics elements. If you specify ASPECT=1, each 
graphics element has equal horizontal and vertical scaling factors; ASPECT=2 
scales the graphics element twice as wide as its height; and so on. If ASPECT= 
is not specified or is set to 0 or null, SAS/GRAPH uses the aspect ratio of the 
hardware device.
Prints a copy of the graph automatically. Same as AUTOCOPY=Y.
Suppresses printing a copy of the graph. Same as AUTOCOPY=N.
Causes the device to feed new paper automatically for the next graph. Same as AUTOFEED=Y.
Suppresses the automatic paper feed. Same as AUTOFEED=N.
Selects the default color for all text and the border.

Specifies the width of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction 
with XMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.
      
Syntax: XPIXELS=width-in-pixels where:

width-in-pixels is a positive integer up to eight digits long (0...99999999).

Specifies the height of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction 
with YMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.
    
Syntax: YPIXELS=height-in-pixels where:

height-in-pixels 
is a positive integer up to eight digits long (0...99999999).
Specifies to write the DESCRIPTION= statement text to the ALT= text in an HTML file.
Specifies not to write the DESCRIPTION= statement text to the ALT= text in an HTML file.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Changes the cell size in order to preserve the number of rows and columns.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Preserves the device's original cell size and temporarily changes the number of rows and columns.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Uses the default setting (ON or OFF) that is controlled by DEVOPTS bit 50 (see DEVOPTS).

Help.#cdata:
Controls whether to change the size of the character cells in order to preserve the number of rows 
and columns specified in the device entry.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Refers to the harware's factory-default setting
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Refers to the paper's long edge.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Refers to the paper's short edge.

Help.#cdata: Specifies which edge of the document is the binding edge.
Specifies to draw a border around the graphics output area.
Specifies not to draw a border around the graphics output area.
Specifies the background color of the graphics output.
Selects the color of the By lines that appear in the graphics output.
Causes the device to use cell alignment.

Suppresses cell alignment, causing the procedure to use the entire procedure output 
area and place axis and tick mark labels without regard to cell alignment.

Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the device-resident font when you do not specify a font in a 
SAS program.

Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the characters using the SIMULATE font and suppresses 
the use of all device--resident fonts, regardless of values you specify in 
other SAS statements.

Specifies a device-resident font by associating a CHARTYPE number with a device-resident 
font. Also defines a default size to use with that font.

Syntax: CHARTYPE=hardware-font-chartype  

hardware-font-chartype 
is a nonnegative integer from 0 to 999. hardware-font-chartype refers to the actual 
number for the device-resident font you want to use as listed in the Chartype window 
of the device entry for the selected device driver. By default, CHARTYPE is 0, which 
is the default device-resident font for the device.
          
Selects the number of the default hardware character set.

Specifies that SAS/GRAPH use the device's hardware circle-drawing capability, 
if available.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software move and draw commands to draw circles and arcs.

Syntax: CMAP=('from-color : to-color' <...,'from-color-n : to-color-n'>)
    
Specifies a color map for the device.
Specifies to collate the output, if collation is supported by the device.
Specifies not to collate the output.

[Syntax: COLORS=<(colors-list | NONE)>] 
    
Specifies the foreground colors used to produce your graphics output if you do 
not specify colors explicitly in program statements.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: SAS predefined color names.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Red-green-blue (RGB) color specifications.

Help.#cdata: Specifies a color type.
Sets the number of columns that the device-resident font uses.
Selects the default color for PATTERN definitions when a color has not been specified.
Specifies the default color for SYMBOL definitions when a color has not been specified.
Selects the default color for all titles, footnotes, and notes, and the border.

Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware dashed-line drawing capability of the device when 
generating graphics output.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the dashed lines.

[Syntax: DASHLINE='dashed-line-hex-string'X] 
    
Specifies which dashed lines should be generated by hardware means if possible.

Scales the lengths of the dashes in a dashed line. Value can be any number greater 
than 0. For example, GOPTIONS DASHSCALE=.5 reduces any existing dash length by 
one-half.

Specifies the length of time between graphs in units of 0.01 seconds. For example, 
to specify a delay of .03 seconds, specify DELAY=3.

[Syntax: DESCRIPTION='text-string' s] 
    
Provides a description of the device entry.

[Syntax: DEVADDR=device-address] 
    
Specifies the location of the device to which the output of device drivers is sent.
Specifies the device driver to which SAS/GRAPH sends the procedure output.

[Syntax: DEVMAP=device-map-name | NONE] 
    
Specifies the device map to be used when device-resident fonts are used.

[Syntax: DEVOPTS='hardware-capabilities-hex-string'X] 
    
Specifies the hardware capabilities of the device.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Indicates that the output device is a graphics device that will be receiving graphics  data; most device drivers use this value.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Indicates that the output device is an IBM 3270 graphics data stream.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the type of the output device.

Specifies that output is displayed on the graphics device but does not affect whether a graph is 
placed in a catalog.

Specifies that output is not displayed on the graphics device but does not affect 
whether a graph is placed in a catalog.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Causes the graphic to be left in place after displaying. This is the default.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Causes the background color to be returned and the graph erased after displaying.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Causes the graphic area to be restored with what was displayed in the area previously.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Indicates that no action is necessary.

Help.#cdata: Specifies what happens to the graphic after it is displayed.

Syntax: DRVINIT1='system-command(s)' | DRVINIT2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and 
can be in upper- or lowercase letters.

Syntax: DRVTERM1='system-command(s)' | DRVTERM2='system-command(s)]
      
where:

system-command(s) specifies a character string that is a valid system command and can 
be in upper- or lowercase letters.

Specifies that the device can be queried for information about the current device 
configuration.

Specifies that the device cannot be queried for information about the current device 
configuration.
Specifies to use duplex printing if available on the device.
Causes the graph to be erased when you press RETURN after the graph has been displayed.

Causes the graph to remain on the display when you press RETURN after the graph 
has been displayed.

Specifies a string up to eight characters long that is a file extension, such as 
GIF or CGM, that you want to append to an external file.
Specifies to use integer-based font processing for faster font rendering.
Specifies not to use integer-based font processing for faster font rendering.
Specifies the font for all By lines on the graphics output.

[Syntax: FCACHE=number-fonts-open] 
    
Specifies the number of system fonts to keep open. Default: FCACHE=3

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Closes the GSF and makes it available to the device after all graphs have been  produced and the procedure or driver terminates.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Closes the GSF after each separate graph is produced and releases it to the device  before sending another.

Help.#cdata:
Controls when the graphics stream file (GSF) is closed when you are using the device 
driver to send graphics output to a hard copy device.

Specifies that a file rather than a storage location is the default destination for 
graphics output.

Specifies that a storage location is the default destination for graphics output, 
unless a file of the same name exists.

Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of 
the device.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill rectangles.

Specifies the number of pixels to move before drawing the next line in a software 
fill of a solid area. 

Range: 0-9999.

If FILLINC is set to 0 or 1, adjacent lines are used (solid fill with no gaps). 
If FILLINC is set to 2, a pixel-width line is skipped before drawing the next 
line of a fill.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Renders fonts in memory using integer rendering routines, which improves character  drawing speed for most host systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Disables the storage or use of rendered versions of Bitstream fonts, but produces  the fonts at their highest resolution.

Help.#cdata: Controls the resolution of Bitstream fonts.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Character file format.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Binary file format.

Help.#cdata: Sets the file format of the metacode file produced by the SAS-supplied part of the Metagraphics device driver.
Sets the default font for all text.
Specifies the default font for the first TITLE line.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Leaves the most visible space between characters and produces a longer string.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Spacing depends on the size of the font. NONE might produce a shorter or longer  string than LOOSE for the same font at different point sizes, because some sizes  add space between the characters while others remove it.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Leaves the least visible space between characters.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Places a fixed amount of space between the characters and does not adjust for  the shape of the character; that is, it does not support kerning.

Help.#cdata:
Controls the amount of space between letters in the SAS-supplied Bitstream fonts 
(Brush, Century, Swiss, and Zapf).

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that a continuous stream of data is written.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the file be host-specific edit format.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that fixed-length records be written.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that records are to be written to the SAS log.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that the records are to be written to the destination whose fileref  is GSASFILE.

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: GACCESS=output-format | 'output-format destination'] 
    
Specifies the format or the destination or both of graphics data written to a device 
or graphics stream file (GSF).

[Syntax: GCLASS=SYSOUT-class] 
    
Specifies the output class for IBM printers.

[Syntax: GCOPIES=(<current-copies><,max-copies>)] 
    
Sets the current and maximum number of copies to print.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Used when sending output to an IEEE attached plotter.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Used when creating an ADMPRINT file for output on 3287-type printers.

Help.#cdata:
Instructs the driver to issue either an FSCOPY or GSCOPY call to GDDM when AUTOCOPY 
is in effect.
Selects a GDDM nickname for the device to which output is sent.
Specifies a GDDM token for the device to which output is sent.
Specifies the JES SYSOUT destination for IBM printers.

[Syntax: GEND='string' <...'string-n'>] 
    
Appends an ASCII string to every graphics data record that is sent to a device 
or file.

[Syntax: GEPILOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
    
Sends a string to a device or file after all graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

[Syntax: GPROLOG='string' <...'string-n'>] 
    
Sends a string to device or file before graphics commands are sent.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

[Syntax: GSTART='string <...'string-n'>] 
    
Prefixes every record of graphics data sent to a device or file with a string of characters.
    
'string' can be either of the following: 

 'hex-string'X
 
 'character-string'

[Syntax: GFORMS='forms-code'] 
    
Specifies the JES form name for IBM printers.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Adds each new graph to the end of the current catalog.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Replaces the contents of the catalog with the graph or graphs produced by a single procedure.

Help.#cdata: Appends to or replaces the graphics output catalog.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip9: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip11: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip12: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip13: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip14: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip15: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip16: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip17: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip18: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip19: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip20: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip21: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip22: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip23: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip24: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip25: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.
ToolTips.@ToolTip26: Protocol module name. Valid only for IBM mainframe systems.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the protocol module to use when routing output directly to a printer or 
creating a graphics stream file (GSF) to send to a device attached to your host 
by a protocol converter.

Allows a return code at procedure termination. If the return code is not 0, the entire 
job might terminate.
Always returns a step code of 0, even if the SAS/GRAPH program produced errors.

[Syntax: GSFLEN=record-length] 
    
Controls the length of records written to the graphics stream file (GSF).
    
record-length: must be a nonnegative integer up to five digits long (0...99999).

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Adds the records to the end of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option or  device parameter.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Sends the records to a device or communications port.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Replaces the existing contents of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME=  graphics option or device parameter.

Help.#cdata:
Specifies the disposition of records written to a graphics stream file (GSF) or to 
a device or communications port by the device driver.

Specifies the fileref of the file or aggregate file location to which graphics stream 
file records are written.
Specifies to write prompt messages to the graphics stream file (GSF).
Specifies not to write prompt messages to the graphics stream file (GSF).

Sets the number of lines of display used for graphics for devices whose displays can 
be divided into graphics and text areas.
Specifies the default unit of measure to use with height specifications.

Specifies the time (in seconds) between each graph displayed in a series. By default, 
GWAIT=0, which means that you must press the RETURN key between each display in a 
series of graphs.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use the hardware CTS and RTS signals.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH send data without providing flow control. Specify NONE  only if the hardware or interface program you are using provides its own flow control.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH use programmed flow control with plotters in eavesdrop mode.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use ASCII characters DC1 and DC3.  (This is not appropriate for some devices.)

Help.#cdata: Specifies the type of flow control used to regulate the flow of data to a hard copy device.

[Syntax: GWRITER='writer-name'] 
    
Specifies the name of the external writer used with IBM printers.

[Syntax: HBY=By line-height <units>] 
    
Specifies the height of By lines generated when you use BY-group processing.

[Syntax: HEADER='command'] 
    
Specifies the command that executes a user-supplied program to create HEADER 
records for the driver.

[Syntax: HEADERFILE=fileref] 
    
Specifies the fileref for the file from which the Metagraphics driver reads 
HEADER records.

[Syntax: HORIGIN=horizontal-offset <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the 
lower-left corner of the graph.

[Syntax: HOSTSPEC='text-string'] 
    
Stores FILENAME statement options in the device entry.

[Syntax: HPOS=columns] 
    
Specifies the number of columns in the graphics output area.

[Syntax: HSIZE=horizontal-size <IN | CM | PT>]
    
Sets the horizontal size of the graphics output area.

[Syntax: HTEXT=text-height <units>] 
    
Specifies the default height of the text in the graphics output.

[Syntax: HTITLE=title-height <units>] 
    
Selects the default height used for the first TITLE line.

[Syntax: IBACK=fileref | 'external-file' | 'URL'| " "]
    
Specifies an image file to display in a graph's background area.

[Syntax: ID='description'] 
    
Specifies the description string used by the Metagraphics driver.
Specifies that any images are to be included in graphics output. This is the default.
Specifies that images are to be withheld from graphics output.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Tile the image within the specified area. This copies the images as many times as  needed to fit the area.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Fit the image within the background area. This stretches the image, if necessary.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the way to display the image file that is specified on the IBACK= option.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the user-written part of the driver be executed outside of SAS/GRAPH.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the user-written part of the Metagraphics driver be invoked after  the procedure is complete.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the user-written part be invoked for each graph.

Help.#cdata: Sets level of interactivity for Metagraphics driver.
Specifies that images are to be displayed as they are received in the browser.
Specifies that images are not to be displayed as they are received in the browser.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Produces box and whisker plots.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that a solid vertical line connect the minimum and maximum Y values for each X value.  Syntax: INTERPOL=HILO<C><option> where:  C draws tick marks at the close value instead of at the mean value. option: B connects the minimum and maximum Y values with bars instead of lines.  J joins the mean values or the close values (if HILOC is specified) with a line.  T adds tops and bottoms to each line.  BJ connects maximum and minimum values with a bar and joins the mean or close values.  TJ adds tops and bottoms to the lines and joins the mean or close values.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Connects data points with straight lines.
ToolTips.@ToolTip4:
Specifies a Lagrange interpolation to smooth the plot line. Syntax: INTERPOL=L

where: degree: 1 | 3 | 5 specifies the degree of the Lagrange interpolation polynomial. By default, degree is 1. P specifies a parametric interpolation. S sorts a data set by the independent variable before plotting its data.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that an empty pattern fill the polygon that has been defined by the data points.
ToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies that a solid pattern fill the polygon that has been defined by the data points.
ToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies that a shaded pattern fill the polygon that has been defined by the data points.  Syntax: Mdensity<style<angle>> where: density: 1 produces the lightest shading, and 5 produces the heaviest. style specifies the direction of pattern lines: N parallel lines (the default), X crosshatched lines. degree (0...360): the degree at which the parallel lines are drawn. By default, angle is 0 (lines  are parallel to the horizontal axis).
ToolTips.@ToolTip8: Draws a vertical line from each data point to a horizontal line at the 0 value on the vertical axis  or the minimum value on the vertical axis.
ToolTips.@ToolTip9: Suppresses any interpolation and, if the VALUE= option is not specified, also suppresses plot points.
ToolTips.@ToolTip10: Specifies that a plot is a regression analysis.  Syntax: INTERPOL=R<type><0><CLM | CLI<50...99>> where: type: L requests linear regression (default); Q requests quadratic regression; C requests cubic regression.  Specifiy 0 to force the regression line through a (0,0) origin. CLM displays confidence limits for mean predicted values. CLI displays confidence limits for individual predicted values.
ToolTips.@ToolTip11: Specifies that a smooth line is fit to data using a spline routine.
ToolTips.@ToolTip12: Specifies that the interpolation for the plot line use a spline routine. INTERPOL=SPLINE produces the smoothest line and is the most efficient of the nontrivial spline interpolation methods.
ToolTips.@ToolTip13: Specifies that a solid line connect the mean Y value with ± 1, 2, or 3 standard deviations for each X.
ToolTips.@ToolTip14: Specifies that the data are plotted with a step function.  Syntax: INTERPOL=STEP<placement><J><S> where: placement: L displays the data point on the left of the step. R displays the data point on the right of the step.  C displays the data point in the center of the step.  For the other options: J produces steps joined with a vertical line. S sorts unordered data by the  independent variable before plotting.

Help.#cdata: Sets the default interpolation value for the SYMBOL statement.

[Syntax: ITERATION=iteration-count] 
    
Specifies the number of times to repeat the animation loop.

[Syntax: KEYMAP=key-map-name | NONE] 
    
Selects the keymap to use.

[Syntax: LCOLS=landscape-columns] 
    
Sets the number of columns in the graphics output area for landscape orientation. 

landscape-columns 
must be a nonnegative integer up to three digits long (0...999).

[Syntax: LFACTOR=line-thickness-factor] 
    
Selects the default hardware line thickness.

[Syntax: LROWS=landscape-rows] 
    
Sets the number of  rows in the graphics output area for landscape orientation. 

landscape-rows 
must be a nonnegative integer up to three digits long (0...999).

[Syntax: OFFSHADOW=(x <units>, y <units>) | (x,y) <units>]

Controls the width and depth of the drop shadow in legend frames.

[Syntax: PAPERDEST=bin] 
    
Specifies which output bin (name or number) the printer should use if multiple 
bins are available on the device.

Syntax: PAPERFEED=feed-increment <IN | CM> 
    
Specifies the increment of paper that is ejected when a graph is completed. 
    
feed-increment must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit specification, either 
IN for inches (default) or CM for centimeters.

[Syntax: PAPERLIMIT=width <IN | CM> where:
    
width specifies the paper width in IN for inches (default) or CM for centimeters.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: LETTER paper size.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: LEGAL paper size.

Help.#cdata: Specifies the name of a paper size.

Syntax: PAPERSOURCE=tray 

where: tray specifies the name or number of the paper tray.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: GLOSSY paper type
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: PLAIN paper type

Help.#cdata:
[Syntax: PAPERTYPE='type-name'] 
    
Specifies the name of a paper type.

Stores clipped polygons with the graph in the default catalog WORK.GSEG, or in the 
catalog you specify.

Stores the unclipped form of the polygon and causes the polygon to be clipped 
when replayed.

Syntax: PENMOUNTS=active-pen-mounts
    
where: 

active-pen-mounts 
specifies the number of pens for a plotter with multiple pens. After the specified number of pens 
have been used, you are prompted to change the pens.
Causes the plotter to draw all graphics elements of one color at one time.
Causes the plotter to draw each element as it is encountered, regardless of its color.

Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device, if available, 
to fill pies and pie sections.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to fill pies and pie sections using software pie fills.

Specifies polygon clipping, which enables a clipped polygon to be filled with a 
hardware pattern.

Specifies line clipping; a polygon that has been line-clipped cannot use a hardware 
pattern.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device to fill polygons.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill polygons.

Specifies data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gepilog field 
of the device entry is sent.
      
Syntax: POSTGEPILOG='string' 
 
where: 

'string' can be either of the following: 

    'hex-string'X
 
    'character-string'

Specifies the data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gprolog 
field of the device entry is sent.
    
Syntax: POSTGPROLOG='string' 
 
where: 

'string' can be either of the following: 

    'hex-string'X
 
    'character-string'

Syntax: POSTGRAPH1='system-command(s)'

where: 

system-command(s) 
specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain upper- or 
lowercase characters.

Syntax: PPDFILE=fileref | 'external-file'
    
where: 

fileref specifies a fileref that points to the PPD file you want to use.

external-file specifies the complete filename of the PPD file you want to use.

Specifies data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gepilog 
field of the device entry is sent.
    
Syntax: PREGEPILOG='string' 

where:

'string' can be either of the following: 

    'hex-string'X
 
    'character-string'

Specifies the data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gprolog 
field of the device entry is sent.
    
Syntax: PREGPROLOG='string' where:

'string' can be either of the following: 

    'hex-string'X
 
    'character-string'

Syntax: PREGRAPH1='system-command(s)' where:
    
system-command(s) specifies one or more valid system commands. The string can contain 
upper- or lowercase characters.
Causes all prompts to be displayed.
Suppresses all prompts. NOPROMPT overrides the GWAIT= graphics option.

[Syntax: PROMPTCHARS='prompt-chars-hex-string'X] 
    
Selects the prompt characters to be used by SAS/GRAPH device drivers.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Creates files to store rendered versions of Bitstream fonts if the files do not  already exist, reads previously rendered characters from the font files, and  appends rendered versions of new characters to the font files when the SAS/GRAPH  procedure terminates.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Creates files to store rendered versions of Bitstream fonts if the files do not  already exist, reads previously rendered characters from the font files, and  appends rendered versions of new characters to the font files as they are  encountered.
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Renders all fonts in memory without creating any font files on disk. Font files  are not used even if they already exist.
ToolTips.@ToolTip5: Reads existing rendered font files but does not create new font files or write  new characters to existing font files.

Help.#cdata: Controls the creation and disposition of rendered Bitstream fonts.
Specifies the SAS library in which rendered font files are stored.

Specifies how many times to redraw the graph.

Syntax: REPAINT=redraw-factor where:

redraw-factor is a nonnegative integer up to three digits long (0...999).

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets all graphics options to defaults and cancels all global statements.
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Cancels all global statements (AXIS, FOOTNOTE, LEGEND, PATTERN, SYMBOL, and TITLE).
ToolTips.@ToolTip3: Syntaxt: RESET=statement-name|(statement-name(s))                 Resets or cancels only the specified global statements.

Help.#cdata: Resets graphics options to their defaults and/or cancels global statements.
Specifies to print the output in reverse order, if reverse printing is supported by the device.
Specifies not to print the output in reverse order.
Specifies to rotate the graph 90 degrees from its default orientation.
Specifies not to rotate the graph 90 degrees from its default orientation.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies landscape orientation (the graph is wider than it is high).
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies portrait orientation (the graph is higher than it is wide).

Help.#cdata: Specifies whether and how to rotate the graph.

Syntax: SIMFONT=SAS/GRAPH-font where:
    
SAS/GRAPH-font specifies a SAS/GRAPH font to use instead of the default device-resident font.

Selects pen speed for plotters with variable speed selection.
    
Syntax: SPEED=pen-speed where:

pen-speed specifies a percentage (1 through 100) of the maximum pen speed for the device.
Swaps BLACK for WHITE and vice versa.
Does not swap the colors. A blank Swap field in the Parameters window is the same as SWAP=N.

ToolTips.@ToolTip1: Uses polygon rendering
ToolTips.@ToolTip2: uses scanline rendering

Help.#cdata: Specifies the method used to render system fonts.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in symbol-drawing capability of the device, if available.
Causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the symbols using SAS/GRAPH fonts.

Displays the output as it would appear on a different device. Also, specifies the device driver 
for the PRINT command.
    
Syntax: TARGETDEVICE=target-device-entry where:
 
target-device-entry 
specifies the name of a device entry in a catalog.
See TARGETDEVICE= option.

Specifies that the background of the image should appear to be transparent when the image is 
displayed in the browser.

Specifies that the background of the image should not appear to be transparent when the image is 
displayed in the browser.

Selects a translate table for your system that performs ASCII-to-EBCDIC translation.
    
Syntax: TRANTAB=table | user-defined-table w

here:

table: specifies a translate table stored as a SAS/GRAPH catalog entry. Table can be 
one of the following: 

      SASGTAB0 (default translate table for your operating environment)
 
      GTABVTAM
 
      GTABTCAM 

user-defined-table: specifies the name of a user-created translate table.

Sets the user-defined control characters for the device.
    
Syntax: UCC='control-characters-hex-string'X where:

control-characters-hex-string is a hexadecimal string that can be up 32 bytes 
(64 characters) long.
Enables user input
Disables user input

Sets the vertical offset from the lower-left corner of the display area to the 
lower-left corner of the graph.
    
Syntax: VORIGIN=vertical-offset <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-offset must be a nonnegative number and can be followed by a unit 
specification, either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT 
for points.

Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: VPOS=rows  where:

rows specifies the number of rows in the graphics output area, which is equivalent 
to the number of hardware characters that can be displayed vertically. Specifying 
VPOS=0 causes the device driver to use the default hardware character cell height 
for the device.

Sets the vertical size of the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: VSIZE=vertical-size <IN | CM | PT> where:

vertical-size specifies the height of the graphics output area; 
vertical-size must be a positive number and can be followed by a unit specification, 
either IN for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.
Causes SAS/GRAPH programs to use these Version 6 behaviors.
Causes SAS/GRAPH programs to use all the features of the current SAS version.

Specifies the width of the addressable graphics display area; affects the horizontal 
resolution of the device and the horizontal dimension of the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: XMAX=width <IN | CM | PT>  where:

width is a positive number that can be followed by a unit specification, either IN for 
inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

Specifies the height of the addressable graphics display area; affects the vertical 
resolution of the device and the vertical dimension of the graphics output area.
    
Syntax: YMAX=height <IN | CM | PT>  where:

height is a positive number that can be followed by a unit specification, either IN 
for inches (default), or CM for centimeters, or PT for points.
